category_summary:
**Anthropic** dominated discussions with their [4th Economic Index report](/?date=2026-01-16&category=social#item-920de3aba6cb) introducing 'economic primitives' metrics, alongside quantitative data showing **Claude** [achieves 50% success](/?date=2026-01-16&category=social#item-38c99ba47a32) on 3.5-hour tasks. Their [AI for Science program](/?date=2026-01-16&category=social#item-6f8abb0bf285) revealed concrete examples of AI accelerating research discoveries.

- **Google DeepMind** released **TranslateGemma**, open translation models supporting 55 languages in 4B-27B parameter sizes, trained via knowledge distillation from **Gemini**
- **John Carmack** [continued his #PaperADay](/?date=2026-01-16&category=social#item-1c087863df29) technical reviews; **Fei-Fei Li** [shared new robotics research](/?date=2026-01-16&category=social#item-892add91239e) on interactive 3D world models
- **Ethan Mollick** [highlighted Anthropic's role](/?date=2026-01-16&category=social#item-1e07f307f1c7) in establishing agent paradigms (MCPs, Skills) that become industry standards
- **LlamaIndex** founder [argued 'files are all you need'](/?date=2026-01-16&category=social#item-7a14ec003155) for agent architecture; **Neel Nanda's** MATS scholars [proposed using CCP-censored facts](/?date=2026-01-16&category=social#item-b655c1749505) as interpretability ground truth

Cultural concerns emerged around AI-generated influencers, with [viral discussion of 'fake e-girl'](/?date=2026-01-16&category=social#item-dc446f87cbcc) content signaling a societal inflection point for synthetic media authenticity.

items.title:
#PaperADay 6
LOCAL FEATURE SWAPPING FOR GENERALIZATION IN REINFORCEMENT LEARNING
https://t.co/n1xj5B...
items.content:
#PaperADay 6
LOCAL FEATURE SWAPPING FOR GENERALIZATION IN REINFORCEMENT LEARNING
https://t.co/n1xj5BRqNX

There is a good discussion of generalization, both in general (ha) and more specifically in RL, but the idea presented is very simple, and I‚Äôm going to give it a try:

CLOP: Channel-consistent local permutations
Given a 3D tensor (4D with batch), with some probability at each location, randomly swap position with a neighbor, swapping all channels as a unit. Like dropout, this reduces overfitting by co-adaptation, but it doesn‚Äôt zero any channels out, it just moves them.

I agree with the idea that data augmentation in the latent space is more efficient for generalization than in the input space. They suggest doing it as low in the spatial hierarchy as possible, but it probably wouldn‚Äôt be a good idea at a 2x2 level, where there are only four possible permutations and any of them disturb half the spatial information.

Note that they tuned the swap chance per-game, which is generally not done when reporting results on a suite of games.

The results on pure supervised learning tasks weren‚Äôt noteworthy, but might be better with the CLOP inserted in different places and with different training recipes.

Discusses CLOP (Channel-consistent local permutations) technique for reducing overfitting in RL by swapping neighboring positions in tensors while maintaining channel consistency. Notes data augmentation in latent space is more efficient than input space.

There is a good discussion of generalization, both in general (ha) and more specifically in RL, but the idea presented is very simple, and I‚Äôm going to give it a try:

CLOP: Channel-consistent local permutations

Given a 3D tensor (4D with batch), with some probability at each location, randomly swap position with a neighbor, swapping all channels as a unit. Like dropout, this reduces overfitting by co-adaptation, but it doesn‚Äôt zero any channels out, it just moves them.

I agree with the idea that data augmentation in the latent space is more efficient for generalization than in the input space. They suggest doing it as low in the spatial hierarchy as possible, but it probably wouldn‚Äôt be a good idea at a 2x2 level, where there are only four possible permutations and any of them disturb half the spatial information.

Note that they tuned the swap chance per-game, which is generally not done when reporting results on a suite of games.

The results on pure supervised learning tasks weren‚Äôt noteworthy, but might be better with the CLOP inserted in different places and with different training recipes.

items.title:
Files are all you need üóÇÔ∏è

I wrote a blog post to capture a trend I‚Äôm seeing in the AI agent landsca...
items.content:
Files are all you need üóÇÔ∏è

I wrote a blog post to capture a trend I‚Äôm seeing in the AI agent landscape: that the primary way to equip agents with actions and context is through files and filesystems.
1Ô∏è‚É£ It is an easy way for agents to store context for later (e.g. @dexhorthy‚Äôs progressive disclosure)
2Ô∏è‚É£ It is a powerful search interface, in addition to or instead of RAG
3Ô∏è‚É£ It is a more flexible way to equip agents with tool calling.

Coding agents + file tools are a good initial proxy for computer use. We‚Äôll see if the trend persists, but there‚Äôs a ton more potential to explore here.

Blog: https://t.co/wxEmvgan4w

I wrote a blog post to capture a trend I‚Äôm seeing in the AI agent landscape: that the primary way to equip agents with actions and context is through files and filesystems.

1Ô∏è‚É£ It is an easy way for agents to store context for later (e.g. @dexhorthy‚Äôs progressive disclosure)

2Ô∏è‚É£ It is a powerful search interface, in addition to or instead of RAG

Coding agents + file tools are a good initial proxy for computer use. We‚Äôll see if the trend persists, but there‚Äôs a ton more potential to explore here.

@ErrataRob He also is good friends with Elon. 

He's the reason I got the first ride in the first Tesla with Elon. 

I'm planning on going to China to tour robot companies to have a good baseline before Elon shows off Optimus 3. 

To be fair to Jason, lots of people have said that about Tesla Self Driving over the years and they all were wrong.

So the game is early.

items.title: Typical LLMs reason by producing words one at a time‚Äîif you ask them to solve a problem step by step...
items.content:
Typical LLMs reason by producing words one at a time‚Äîif you ask them to solve a problem step by step, each intermediate thought must be spelled out as text before the model can continue.

This paper asks the following question: what if the model could just keep thinking internally without being forced to commit its half-formed ideas to language?

The authors take the hidden numerical representation that exists inside the model right before it picks the next word, and instead of converting it to text, they feed it directly back as the next input. The model can then chain several of these internal "thoughts" together before finally outputting words.

It turns out that training this way results in an interesting observation: the internal representation seems to hold multiple possible reasoning paths at once, and the model gradually narrows down to the correct answer over several steps‚Äîrather than committing early to a single path and getting stuck.

On problems that require exploring different options before deciding (like navigating a graph), this internal reasoning outperforms the standard word-by-word approach while using fewer computational steps.

Read with an AI tutor: https://t.co/iCNNIds3gw

Read alone: https://t.co/2GTpDn8Dk6
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov explains paper on internal reasoning: feeding hidden representations back as input instead of converting to text, allowing models to hold multiple reasoning paths before committing.
items.reasoning: Detailed technical explanation of significant research on non-verbal reasoning in LLMs. Educational content from known ML author.
items.summary_html: Burkov explains paper on internal reasoning: feeding hidden representations back as input instead of converting to text, allowing models to hold multiple reasoning paths before committing.

items.title: Cursor is becoming obsolete because Claude Code just does everything faster and better, so they are ...
items.content:
Cursor is becoming obsolete because Claude Code just does everything faster and better, so they are trying to hype "generative AI" when it's already looking lame.

If you ask an agentic coding system with a runtime feedback loop to build an app whose meaning is clear, like "web browser" or "tetris" or "spreadsheet processor," it will no doubt build it because:

1. It knows what the correct performance looks like and can see the current performance from screenshots.

2. It has seen plenty of code that implements this kind of app.

If you want to impress anyone, ask it to build an app that controls plasma in a cold fusion reactor or any working quantum computer program that is considered unsolved yet by science and whose code couldn't leak into your training set.

Otherwise, it's once again, "Oh, look, these balls are jumping inside these rotating octagons!"

2. It has seen plenty of code that implements this kind of app.

If you want to impress anyone, ask it to build an app that controls plasma in a cold fusion reactor or any working quantum computer program that is considered unsolved yet by science and whose code couldn't leak into your training set.

items.title: Just had Claude Code build me a full health projection based on one year's worth of daily scale data...
items.content:
Just had Claude Code build me a full health projection based on one year's worth of daily scale data. 

I have hundreds of data points on my weight, body water, skeletal muscle, metabolic age, and a whole bunch of statistics that I'm sure Bryan Johnson tracks every millisecond. 

I opened the scale app, took 14 screenshots of the graphs, airdropped to my computer, opened up Claude Code, said:

"Hey, look at the 14 most recent files in my downloads. also access my personal life context doc and my business life context doc in our claude context folder. build out full projections for all 13 variables. lay out all strengths and weaknesses. make all recommendations custom to my context."

It was done in minutes.

Tracking more of your health and context is a massive upgrade for your AI use.
items.author: @alliekmiller
items.summary: Allie K Miller demonstrates using Claude Code for personal health data analysis - fed 14 screenshots of scale data plus personal context docs to get custom health projections and recommendations in minutes.
items.reasoning: Practical AI use case with high engagement (102 likes, 11k views). Demonstrates multimodal input + context docs workflow. From recognized AI advisor.
items.summary_html: Allie K Miller demonstrates using Claude Code for personal health data analysis - fed 14 screenshots of scale data plus personal context docs to get custom health projections and recommendations in minutes.
items.content_html:
Just had Claude Code build me a full health projection based on one year's worth of daily scale data.

I have hundreds of data points on my weight, body water, skeletal muscle, metabolic age, and a whole bunch of statistics that I'm sure Bryan Johnson tracks every millisecond.

I opened the scale app, took 14 screenshots of the graphs, airdropped to my computer, opened up Claude Code, said:

"Hey, look at the 14 most recent files in my downloads. also access my personal life context doc and my business life context doc in our claude context folder. build out full projections for all 13 variables. lay out all strengths and weaknesses. make all recommendations custom to my context."

It was done in minutes.

Tracking more of your health and context is a massive upgrade for your AI use.

items.title:
Indexing your content is not the same as scraping your content.

Everyone wants Google to index thei...
items.content:
Indexing your content is not the same as scraping your content.

Everyone wants Google to index their content. Nobody wants Google or any other AI lab to scrape it.

Developers and content creators know how to build businesses where we give our work away for free and rely on search engines for attribution and page views.

But if you scrape our content and cut all traffic to the source, we won't keep feeding you.

This should not be hard to understand.

If there's no incentive to keep publishing, nobody will.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago Pino argues indexing vs scraping distinction is crucial - developers want search attribution, not content extraction that kills traffic to sources
items.reasoning: 69 likes on important AI ethics/economics topic. Clear articulation of creator concerns about AI training data that resonates with developer community.
items.summary_html: Santiago Pino argues indexing vs scraping distinction is crucial - developers want search attribution, not content extraction that kills traffic to sources
items.content_html:
Indexing your content is not the same as scraping your content.

Everyone wants Google to index their content. Nobody wants Google or any other AI lab to scrape it.

Developers and content creators know how to build businesses where we give our work away for free and rely on search engines for attribution and page views.

But if you scrape our content and cut all traffic to the source, we won't keep feeding you.

This should not be hard to understand.

If there's no incentive to keep publishing, nobody will.

items.title: @CalcCon @ChrisRoper It‚Äôs theoretically impossible to reliably detect AI text if the model is traine...
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov argues AI text detection is theoretically impossible since LLMs are trained to match human text distribution - any stable difference gets erased.
items.reasoning: Clear technical argument about fundamental limitations of AI detection.
items.summary_html: Burkov argues AI text detection is theoretically impossible since LLMs are trained to match human text distribution - any stable difference gets erased.
items.content_html:
@CalcCon @ChrisRoper It‚Äôs theoretically impossible to reliably detect AI text if the model is trained properly. The whole point of LLM training is to punish outputs that don‚Äôt look human.

So an "AI detector" is basically trying to learn the exact opposite signal - find differences the generator is actively trained to erase.

Once the model distribution matches human text closely enough, any detector collapses to chance. It's not "Google needs a better NN," it's "there‚Äôs no stable difference left."

items.title:
Cloud computing for the AI world.

I visited @gmi_cloud's headquarters on Monday. This is a company ...
items.content:
Cloud computing for the AI world.

I visited @gmi_cloud's headquarters on Monday. This is a company that only hosts GPUs for many companies building, and running, AI models. 

I worked for Rackspace for seven years back when it was a hot Web hosting company and this one is that, but for the AI age. 

Company to use to build, or inference, your AI models on. Only has GPUs in its datacenters and, unlike the other big ones, like AWS or Google Cloud, it is wholly focused on the AI world.

Highly impressed.

items.title:
The architecture of @PixVerse_'s model has three critical pieces:

1. A native multimodal foundation...
items.content:
The architecture of @PixVerse_'s model has three critical pieces:

1. A native multimodal foundation model that unifies text, image, video, and audio into one token stream.

2. An autoregressive memory mechanism that maintains consistency across indefinitely long sequences.

3. An "Instantaneous Response Engine" that cuts sampling steps from dozens down to 1-4.

That last part is key: it's what makes this model work in real time.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Explains PixVerse-R1 architecture: multimodal foundation model, autoregressive memory, and 'Instantaneous Response Engine' reducing sampling to 1-4 steps

items.summary_html: Explains PixVerse-R1 architecture: multimodal foundation model, autoregressive memory, and 'Instantaneous Response Engine' reducing sampling to 1-4 steps

The architecture of @PixVerse_'s model has three critical pieces:

2. An autoregressive memory mechanism that maintains consistency across indefinitely long sequences.

3. An "Instantaneous Response Engine" that cuts sampling steps from dozens down to 1-4.

That last part is key: it's what makes this model work in real time.

items.title:
We have a serious problem with fine-tuning.

Anyone trying to do SFT or RL today is forced into one ...
items.content:
We have a serious problem with fine-tuning.

Anyone trying to do SFT or RL today is forced into one of two extremes:

1."Easy-to-use" APIs that give you almost no control over the training process.

2.Full-on infrastructure hell, where you deal with checkpoints, raw GPUs, retries, idle costs, and endless plumbing.

There's very little in between.

I've talked to a few teams that have to choose the lesser of these two evils. Most end up spending a ton of money on people who can handle infrastructure because they have no other choice.

Here is a different alternative:

The HPC-AI team just released a fine-tuning SDK that gives you full control over your training code without dealing with infrastructure hell:

‚Ä¢ You get custom SFT recipes
‚Ä¢ RL or RLVR (Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards)
‚Ä¢ You can use your own reward functions
‚Ä¢ You can use your own training loops

They handle everything on the infrastructure side:

‚Ä¢ You never touch Kubernetes configs
‚Ä¢ You never touch cluster schedulers
‚Ä¢ You never touch GPU provisioning
‚Ä¢ You never touch distributed checkpoint plumbing

This opens up fine-tuning to many more teams.

You no longer have to choose between "too simple to be useful" and "so complex it's a nightmare."

The key idea here is very simple: This model decouples algorithm design from infrastructure engineering.

There's something else:

With this model, you pay per token rather than renting GPUs by the hour and dealing with idle clusters.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago Pino discusses fine-tuning infrastructure gap: either too-simple APIs or full infrastructure complexity, announces HPC-AI SDK as middle ground solution
items.reasoning: Identifies real industry pain point in fine-tuning workflow. Partially promotional but articulates genuine infrastructure challenge.

items.title: @ChrisRoper "The analysis focused explicitly on identifying fully AI-generated content rather than p...
items.content:
@ChrisRoper "The analysis focused explicitly on identifying fully AI-generated content rather than partial or assisted use. Classification was based on within-account comparison, stylistic consistency and repetition patterns, the absence of factual anchoring, and stable generative signatures observed across posts and topics. Indicators of automation and cross-posting were recorded as metadata rather than used as exclusion criteria."

Bullshit. That's a scientific term.

items.title:
The future is really bright:

‚Ä¢ A game that generates the environments as you play. 100% on the fly....
items.content:
The future is really bright:

‚Ä¢ A game that generates the environments as you play. 100% on the fly.

‚Ä¢ A movie where the viewer influences the narrative outcomes.

‚Ä¢ Simulations for research, industrial planning, and even ecological modeling that evolve based on decisions.

That's the goal here:

To have "persistent, interactive worlds rather than finite media artifacts."

items.title: A lot of PDFs have charts, and parsing charts is hard. All frontier models out of the box are notori...
items.content:
A lot of PDFs have charts, and parsing charts is hard. All frontier models out of the box are notoriously bad at interpreting chart values without explicit guidance.

There‚Äôs a lot of ways you can throw compute/tokens at the problem (gpt-5.2-pro is pretty good), and there‚Äôs still a bunch of edge cases we need to fix.

We‚Äôve created some awesome visual understanding capabilities within LlamaParse at a cheap price. Our agentic mode supports good approximate chart parsing at 1c per page (lower with cost optimization/discounts), less than our comparable solutions at a few cents a page.

In the picture below we overlaid a source line chart with our parsed chart on top. For simple line charts it basically matches perfectly.

Whether it‚Äôs a financial report or marketing presentation, check out our agentic mode + agentic parsing toggles to help OCR your docs!

Sign up: https://t.co/QwzurFBE67
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu promotes LlamaParse chart parsing capabilities - agentic mode at 1c/page can parse charts from PDFs that frontier models struggle with
items.reasoning: Product update from LlamaIndex founder addressing real pain point (chart OCR). Notes GPT-5.2-Pro works well but expensive.
items.summary_html: Jerry Liu promotes LlamaParse chart parsing capabilities - agentic mode at 1c/page can parse charts from PDFs that frontier models struggle with
items.content_html:
A lot of PDFs have charts, and parsing charts is hard. All frontier models out of the box are notoriously bad at interpreting chart values without explicit guidance.

There‚Äôs a lot of ways you can throw compute/tokens at the problem (gpt-5.2-pro is pretty good), and there‚Äôs still a bunch of edge cases we need to fix.

We‚Äôve created some awesome visual understanding capabilities within LlamaParse at a cheap price. Our agentic mode supports good approximate chart parsing at 1c per page (lower with cost optimization/discounts), less than our comparable solutions at a few cents a page.

In the picture below we overlaid a source line chart with our parsed chart on top. For simple line charts it basically matches perfectly.

Whether it‚Äôs a financial report or marketing presentation, check out our agentic mode + agentic parsing toggles to help OCR your docs!

items.title:
@amorriscode Am still on client calls but had a teammate test on 2 tasks. 

Review v positive on fun...
items.content:
@amorriscode Am still on client calls but had a teammate test on 2 tasks. 

Review v positive on functionality. Cleaned up her entire desktop in minutes. Wished the code readout design was a little more clear (ie a different treatment for task bullets versus text replies to better distinguish them on a re-read since you have control of the UI). Said she was surprised the keyboard shortcuts were in Code terminal and Cowork but not Code desktop (and said "could have just been what task I tested but I'm surprised I'm replying in text when it gave me a numbered list"). Said the permission popups were annoying and stacked. Overall, she said she liked it enough that it made her dislike Cowork even more by comparison.

items.summary: Allie Miller shares teammate's review of a product - positive on functionality (cleaned desktop in minutes), criticisms on UI clarity and permission popup stacking, prefers it over Cowork.

items.title:
There are several limitations with real-time video generation:

1. Small prediction errors compound ...
items.content:
There are several limitations with real-time video generation:

1. Small prediction errors compound over extended sequences

2. Computational costs are high (and are still a bottleneck)

We are early, but the trajectory here is looking pretty good!
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Lists limitations of real-time video generation: error compounding and computational costs
items.reasoning: Balanced technical assessment of current limitations in real-time video AI
items.summary_html: Lists limitations of real-time video generation: error compounding and computational costs
items.content_html:
There are several limitations with real-time video generation:

1. Small prediction errors compound over extended sequences

2. Computational costs are high (and are still a bottleneck)

We are early, but the trajectory here is looking pretty good!

items.title: It's easy to get lost when reading traces.  An effective heuristic is to stop at the first (most ups...
items.content:
It's easy to get lost when reading traces.  An effective heuristic is to stop at the first (most upstream) error you find and move on when doing error analysis.

You can then modify and curate traces for evals.

BTW this is flashcard 9/12 (links in reply). https://t.co/4pPnCig4ez

items.title: The Zayed Sustainability Prize awards ceremony at Abu Dhabi Sustainability Week brings together proj...
items.content:
The Zayed Sustainability Prize awards ceremony at Abu Dhabi Sustainability Week brings together projects from very different regions, showing how sustainability progress is taking shape through practical solutions in water, energy, food, and healthcare

@ADSWagenda Partner #ADSW

What stands out is how technology, including AI, is supporting both innovation and impact assessment. Measuring and verifying results matters, particularly when solutions scale across communities and geographies.

The Prize reflects a long-term approach to sustainability, where vision, execution, and accountability translate into tangible outcomes for millions of people.

items.title: @teethrichards The situation with KDP was the following: Amazon makes you create a separate account ...
items.content:
@teethrichards The situation with KDP was the following: Amazon makes you create a separate account for each Amazon version: com, ca, fr, de, etc. What they don't tell you is that in their system it's still one account.

So, I saw that I had a separate **empty** KDP account on https://t.co/ivP6eTZwpX. I decided to close it. Amazon deleted my KDP account entirely, including a non-empty one on https://t.co/LMWJFQkwUG and erased all my books. They even erased the records of all the royalties I received, of all bank transfers they made to me. They literally couldn't verify that I had been their client for years. I forwarded them numerous emails I received from KDP in the past. They didn't care.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov shares Amazon KDP horror story about account deletion erasing all books and royalty records.
items.reasoning: Personal experience with platform issues, tangentially related to tech.
items.summary_html: Burkov shares Amazon KDP horror story about account deletion erasing all books and royalty records.
items.content_html:
@teethrichards The situation with KDP was the following: Amazon makes you create a separate account for each Amazon version: com, ca, fr, de, etc. What they don't tell you is that in their system it's still one account.

So, I saw that I had a separate empty KDP account on https://t.co/ivP6eTZwpX. I decided to close it. Amazon deleted my KDP account entirely, including a non-empty one on https://t.co/LMWJFQkwUG and erased all my books. They even erased the records of all the royalties I received, of all bank transfers they made to me. They literally couldn't verify that I had been their client for years. I forwarded them numerous emails I received from KDP in the past. They didn't care.

https://t.co/qzbRGb5Zos

This code will give you $10 in free vouchers (approximately 1.5M tokens) to run your first training job.

And here is the GitHub Repository with the SDK:

https://t.co/3DMqEeyfAC

Thanks to the HPC-AI team for partnering with me on this post.

items.title:
Because games aren't as interesting as REAL LIFE

But when you're 12 your life consists of waking up...
items.content:
Because games aren't as interesting as REAL LIFE

But when you're 12 your life consists of waking up, going to school, being bored at school, coming home, having 10,000 rules by parents, can't do anything without their permission

So no shit games are fun then because it gives you freedom and also your life is boring

Now you're a grownup you have ALL THE FREEDOM in the world to do anything, go anywhere, talk to anyone

How would a video game ever compare?

GTA 5 or Cyberpunk 2077 is extremely limited compared to what I can do in my life and what I did already so to me it's just extremely boring

But I still play a bit but it's just tedious and boring so I keep quitting

items.content_html:
@theresidency Yeah, residencies are coming on strong. I've visited several in San Francisco, and I've got to come over and see you all and hang out with your startups.

There's a network effect that happens in a residency, with each startup helping each other, and it's a brilliant move. It's a reaction, actually, to Y Combinator. They were the leader in doing this kind of thing, but the game is changing, and it's interesting to watch how it continues to change.

Love what you all do!

It seems like they're finally turning it on.

items.title: @cwRichardKim Queuing messages (pinging the same thread multiple times before it responds) is what I...
items.content:
@cwRichardKim Queuing messages (pinging the same thread multiple times before it responds) is what I'm referring to. I shouldn't have to scroll up to see all the pings. 

Having multiple threads on the left hand rail replying/taking action at the same time is the multi-tasking I refer to in the rest of the tweet. A win as a capability but the UI of chat threads is really subpar. I want to click a button that launches "Multitask mode" and it looks like the NBC 4-screen broadcast of the Olympics. See below. 

How do you save recurring tasks again? Haven't demo'd that I don't think. 

I'll DM you something I sent Scott too.

Under the hood is a unified, promptable vision model built for:

‚Üí Instance-level coverage
‚Üí Robust tracking
‚Üí Interactive accuracy

This is SAM 3 from Meta, rolling into tools you already use.

items.title:
Why this matters for real teams, not demos:

‚Üí Creators
Apply motion-locked effects to people or pro...
items.content:
Why this matters for real teams, not demos:

‚Üí Creators
Apply motion-locked effects to people or props, directly on mobile.

‚Üí ML teams
Speed up dataset labeling without brittle tooling.

‚Üí Researchers
Track species or vehicles across hours of footage with consistency.

Same core system, wildly different outcomes.

That‚Äôs leverage.

items.title:
What surprised me most is how input-flexible this is.

One loop, three ways to control vision:

‚Üí La...
items.content:
What surprised me most is how input-flexible this is.

One loop, three ways to control vision:

‚Üí Language prompts
Type what you want. The model finds every instance.

‚Üí Visual exemplars
No text? Draw one box. Similar objects auto-populate.

‚Üí Click-based refinement
Add positive or negative clicks to fix misses in seconds.

This is interaction, not configuration.

items.content_html:
@ErrataRob @kennethper6943 Some things (I'm on Tesla spaces a lot):

1. Make sure that the glass in front of your cameras is absolutely clean. Have Tesla service clean it.

2. Recalibrate your cameras. It should never hit a curb. Mine never has. 150,000 miles on my HW3 car and my wife has HW4 with 30,000 miles, almost all of which is on FSD. Never had anything like that happen.

items.title: Gary Gygax was in my pantheon of heroes as a teenage D&D player, but I really didn‚Äôt know much about...
items.content:
Gary Gygax was in my pantheon of heroes as a teenage D&D player, but I really didn‚Äôt know much about him before reading this book. The closest I got was asking Margaret Weis, one of the Dragonlance authors and an acquaintance of my father, about him on the phone when I was 13.

The broader impact of D&D (the games at Id Software were briefly mentioned near the end) far exceeded the financial returns for him, and his road was pretty rough, but it sounds like he settled into a pretty good place as ‚Äúking of the nerds‚Äù by the end.

Dying at 69 after a lot of poor health is a reminder for those of us in our 50s to take care of ourselves.

@MikeWitwer
items.author: @ID_AA_Carmack
items.summary: John Carmack reviews biography of Gary Gygax (D&D creator), reflects on his broader cultural impact vs financial returns, notes health reminder for those in their 50s.
items.reasoning: Very high engagement (1000 likes) but not AI-related. Personal book reflection from notable technologist.
items.summary_html: John Carmack reviews biography of Gary Gygax (D&D creator), reflects on his broader cultural impact vs financial returns, notes health reminder for those in their 50s.
items.content_html:
Gary Gygax was in my pantheon of heroes as a teenage D&D player, but I really didn‚Äôt know much about him before reading this book. The closest I got was asking Margaret Weis, one of the Dragonlance authors and an acquaintance of my father, about him on the phone when I was 13.

The broader impact of D&D (the games at Id Software were briefly mentioned near the end) far exceeded the financial returns for him, and his road was pretty rough, but it sounds like he settled into a pretty good place as ‚Äúking of the nerds‚Äù by the end.

Dying at 69 after a lot of poor health is a reminder for those of us in our 50s to take care of ourselves.

@MikeWitwer
